1.verse: In the land of Uz there lived a man whose name was Job. This man was blameless and upright; he feared God and shunned evil.

2.verse: He had seven sons and three daughters,

3.verse: and he owned seven thousand sheep, three thousand camels, five hundred yoke of oxen and five hundred donkeys, and had a large number of servants. He was the greatest man among all the people of the East.

4.verse: His sons used to hold feasts in their homes on their birthdays, and they would invite their three sisters to eat and drink with them.

5.verse: When a period of feasting had run its course, Job would make arrangements for them to be purified. Early in the morning he would sacrifice a burnt offering for each of them, thinking, “Perhaps my children have sinned and cursed God in their hearts.” This was Job’s regular custom.

6.verse: One day the angels came to present themselves before the Lord , and Satan also came with them.

7.verse: The Lord said to Satan, “Where have you come from?”

8.verse: Then the Lord said to Satan, “Have you considered my servant Job? There is no one on earth like him; he is blameless and upright, a man who fears God and shuns evil.”

9.verse: “Does Job fear God for nothing?” Satan replied.

10.verse: “Have you not put a hedge around him and his household and everything he has? You have blessed the work of his hands, so that his flocks and herds are spread throughout the land.

11.verse: But now stretch out your hand and strike everything he has, and he will surely curse you to your face.”

12.verse: The Lord said to Satan, “Very well, then, everything he has is in your power, but on the man himself do not lay a finger.”

13.verse: One day when Job’s sons and daughters were feasting and drinking wine at the oldest brother’s house,

14.verse: a messenger came to Job and said, “The oxen were plowing and the donkeys were grazing nearby,

15.verse: and the Sabeans attacked and made off with them. They put the servants to the sword, and I am the only one who has escaped to tell you!”

16.verse: While he was still speaking, another messenger came and said, “The fire of God fell from the heavens and burned up the sheep and the servants, and I am the only one who has escaped to tell you!”

17.verse: While he was still speaking, another messenger came and said, “The Chaldeans formed three raiding parties and swept down on your camels and made off with them. They put the servants to the sword, and I am the only one who has escaped to tell you!”

18.verse: While he was still speaking, yet another messenger came and said, “Your sons and daughters were feasting and drinking wine at the oldest brother’s house,

19.verse: when suddenly a mighty wind swept in from the desert and struck the four corners of the house. It collapsed on them and they are dead, and I am the only one who has escaped to tell you! ”

20.verse: At this, Job got up and tore his robe and shaved his head. Then he fell to the ground in worship

21.verse: and said:

22.verse: In all this, Job did not sin by charging God with wrongdoing.

1.verse: On another day the angels came to present themselves before the Lord , and Satan also came with them to present himself before him.

2.verse: And the Lord said to Satan, “Where have you come from?”

3.verse: Then the Lord said to Satan, “Have you considered my servant Job? There is no one on earth like him; he is blameless and upright, a man who fears God and shuns evil. And he still maintains his integrity, though you incited me against him to ruin him without any reason.”

4.verse: “Skin for skin!” Satan replied. “A man will give all he has for his own life.

5.verse: But now stretch out your hand and strike his flesh and bones, and he will surely curse you to your face.”

6.verse: The Lord said to Satan, “Very well, then, he is in your hands; but you must spare his life.”

7.verse: So Satan went out from the presence of the Lord and afflicted Job with painful sores from the soles of his feet to the crown of his head.

8.verse: Then Job took a piece of broken pottery and scraped himself with it as he sat among the ashes.

9.verse: His wife said to him, “Are you still maintaining your integrity? Curse God and die!”

10.verse: He replied, “You are talking like a foolish woman. Shall we accept good from God, and not trouble?”

11.verse: When Job’s three friends, Eliphaz the Temanite, Bildad the Shuhite and Zophar the Naamathite, heard about all the troubles that had come upon him, they set out from their homes and met together by agreement to go and sympathize with him and comfort him.

12.verse: When they saw him from a distance, they could hardly recognize him; they began to weep aloud, and they tore their robes and sprinkled dust on their heads.

13.verse: Then they sat on the ground with him for seven days and seven nights. No one said a word to him, because they saw how great his suffering was.

1.verse: After this, Job opened his mouth and cursed the day of his birth.

2.verse: He said:

3.verse: “May the day of my birth perish,

4.verse: That day—may it turn to darkness;

5.verse: May gloom and utter darkness claim it once more;

6.verse: That night—may thick darkness seize it;

7.verse: May that night be barren;

8.verse: May those who curse days curse that day,

9.verse: May its morning stars become dark;

10.verse: for it did not shut the doors of the womb on me

11.verse: “Why did I not perish at birth,

12.verse: Why were there knees to receive me

13.verse: For now I would be lying down in peace;

14.verse: with kings and rulers of the earth,

15.verse: with princes who had gold,

16.verse: Or why was I not hidden away in the ground like a stillborn child,

17.verse: There the wicked cease from turmoil,

18.verse: Captives also enjoy their ease;

19.verse: The small and the great are there,

20.verse: “Why is light given to those in misery,

21.verse: to those who long for death that does not come,

22.verse: who are filled with gladness

23.verse: Why is life given to a man

24.verse: For sighing has become my daily food;

25.verse: What I feared has come upon me;

26.verse: I have no peace, no quietness;

2.verse: “If someone ventures a word with you, will you be impatient?

3.verse: Think how you have instructed many,

4.verse: Your words have supported those who stumbled;

5.verse: But now trouble comes to you, and you are discouraged;

6.verse: Should not your piety be your confidence

7.verse: “Consider now: Who, being innocent, has ever perished?

8.verse: As I have observed, those who plow evil

9.verse: At the breath of God they perish;

10.verse: The lions may roar and growl,

11.verse: The lion perishes for lack of prey,

12.verse: “A word was secretly brought to me,

13.verse: Amid disquieting dreams in the night,

14.verse: fear and trembling seized me

15.verse: A spirit glided past my face,

16.verse: It stopped,

17.verse: ‘Can a mortal be more righteous than God?

18.verse: If God places no trust in his servants,

19.verse: how much more those who live in houses of clay,

20.verse: Between dawn and dusk they are broken to pieces;

21.verse: Are not the cords of their tent pulled up,

1.verse: “Call if you will, but who will answer you?

2.verse: Resentment kills a fool,

3.verse: I myself have seen a fool taking root,

4.verse: His children are far from safety,

5.verse: The hungry consume his harvest,

6.verse: For hardship does not spring from the soil,

7.verse: Yet man is born to trouble

8.verse: “But if I were you, I would appeal to God;

9.verse: He performs wonders that cannot be fathomed,

10.verse: He provides rain for the earth;

11.verse: The lowly he sets on high,

12.verse: He thwarts the plans of the crafty,

13.verse: He catches the wise in their craftiness,

14.verse: Darkness comes upon them in the daytime;

15.verse: He saves the needy from the sword in their mouth;

16.verse: So the poor have hope,

17.verse: “Blessed is the one whom God corrects;

18.verse: For he wounds, but he also binds up;

19.verse: From six calamities he will rescue you;

20.verse: In famine he will deliver you from death,

21.verse: You will be protected from the lash of the tongue,

22.verse: You will laugh at destruction and famine,

23.verse: For you will have a covenant with the stones of the field,

24.verse: You will know that your tent is secure;

25.verse: You will know that your children will be many,

26.verse: You will come to the grave in full vigor,

27.verse: “We have examined this, and it is true.

2.verse: “If only my anguish could be weighed

3.verse: It would surely outweigh the sand of the seas—

4.verse: The arrows of the Almighty are in me,

5.verse: Does a wild donkey bray when it has grass,

6.verse: Is tasteless food eaten without salt,

7.verse: I refuse to touch it;

8.verse: “Oh, that I might have my request,

9.verse: that God would be willing to crush me,

10.verse: Then I would still have this consolation —

11.verse: “What strength do I have, that I should still hope?

12.verse: Do I have the strength of stone?

13.verse: Do I have any power to help myself,

14.verse: “Anyone who withholds kindness from a friend

15.verse: But my brothers are as undependable as intermittent streams,

16.verse: when darkened by thawing ice

17.verse: but that stop flowing in the dry season,

18.verse: Caravans turn aside from their routes;

19.verse: The caravans of Tema look for water,

20.verse: They are distressed, because they had been confident;

21.verse: Now you too have proved to be of no help;

22.verse: Have I ever said, ‘Give something on my behalf,

23.verse: deliver me from the hand of the enemy,

24.verse: “Teach me, and I will be quiet;

25.verse: How painful are honest words!

26.verse: Do you mean to correct what I say,

27.verse: You would even cast lots for the fatherless

28.verse: “But now be so kind as to look at me.

30.verse: Is there any wickedness on my lips?

1.verse: “Do not mortals have hard service on earth?

2.verse: Like a slave longing for the evening shadows,

3.verse: so I have been allotted months of futility,

4.verse: When I lie down I think, ‘How long before I get up?’

5.verse: My body is clothed with worms and scabs,

6.verse: “My days are swifter than a weaver’s shuttle,

7.verse: Remember, O God, that my life is but a breath;

8.verse: The eye that now sees me will see me no longer;

9.verse: As a cloud vanishes and is gone,

10.verse: He will never come to his house again;

11.verse: “Therefore I will not keep silent;

12.verse: Am I the sea, or the monster of the deep,

13.verse: When I think my bed will comfort me

14.verse: even then you frighten me with dreams

15.verse: so that I prefer strangling and death,

16.verse: I despise my life; I would not live forever.

17.verse: “What is mankind that you make so much of them,

18.verse: that you examine them every morning

19.verse: Will you never look away from me,

20.verse: If I have sinned, what have I done to you,

21.verse: Why do you not pardon my offenses

2.verse: “How long will you say such things?

3.verse: Does God pervert justice?

4.verse: When your children sinned against him,

5.verse: But if you will seek God earnestly

6.verse: if you are pure and upright,

7.verse: Your beginnings will seem humble,

8.verse: “Ask the former generation

9.verse: for we were born only yesterday and know nothing,

10.verse: Will they not instruct you and tell you?

11.verse: Can papyrus grow tall where there is no marsh?

12.verse: While still growing and uncut,

13.verse: Such is the destiny of all who forget God;

14.verse: What they trust in is fragile ;

15.verse: They lean on the web, but it gives way;

16.verse: They are like a well-watered plant in the sunshine,

17.verse: it entwines its roots around a pile of rocks

18.verse: But when it is torn from its spot,

19.verse: Surely its life withers away,

20.verse: “Surely God does not reject one who is blameless

21.verse: He will yet fill your mouth with laughter

22.verse: Your enemies will be clothed in shame,

2.verse: “Indeed, I know that this is true.

3.verse: Though they wished to dispute with him,

4.verse: His wisdom is profound, his power is vast.

5.verse: He moves mountains without their knowing it

6.verse: He shakes the earth from its place

7.verse: He speaks to the sun and it does not shine;

8.verse: He alone stretches out the heavens

9.verse: He is the Maker of the Bear and Orion,

10.verse: He performs wonders that cannot be fathomed,

11.verse: When he passes me, I cannot see him;

12.verse: If he snatches away, who can stop him?

13.verse: God does not restrain his anger;

14.verse: “How then can I dispute with him?

15.verse: Though I were innocent, I could not answer him;

16.verse: Even if I summoned him and he responded,

17.verse: He would crush me with a storm

18.verse: He would not let me catch my breath

19.verse: If it is a matter of strength, he is mighty!

20.verse: Even if I were innocent, my mouth would condemn me;

21.verse: “Although I am blameless,

22.verse: It is all the same; that is why I say,

23.verse: When a scourge brings sudden death,

24.verse: When a land falls into the hands of the wicked,

25.verse: “My days are swifter than a runner;

26.verse: They skim past like boats of papyrus,

27.verse: If I say, ‘I will forget my complaint,

28.verse: I still dread all my sufferings,

29.verse: Since I am already found guilty,

30.verse: Even if I washed myself with soap

31.verse: you would plunge me into a slime pit

32.verse: “He is not a mere mortal like me that I might answer him,

33.verse: If only there were someone to mediate between us,

34.verse: someone to remove God’s rod from me,

35.verse: Then I would speak up without fear of him,

2.verse: I say to God: Do not declare me guilty,

3.verse: Does it please you to oppress me,

4.verse: Do you have eyes of flesh?

5.verse: Are your days like those of a mortal

6.verse: that you must search out my faults

7.verse: though you know that I am not guilty

8.verse: “Your hands shaped me and made me.

9.verse: Remember that you molded me like clay.

10.verse: Did you not pour me out like milk

11.verse: clothe me with skin and flesh

12.verse: You gave me life and showed me kindness,

13.verse: “But this is what you concealed in your heart,

14.verse: If I sinned, you would be watching me

15.verse: If I am guilty —woe to me!

16.verse: If I hold my head high, you stalk me like a lion

17.verse: You bring new witnesses against me

18.verse: “Why then did you bring me out of the womb?

19.verse: If only I had never come into being,

20.verse: Are not my few days almost over?

21.verse: before I go to the place of no return,

22.verse: to the land of deepest night,

2.verse: “Are all these words to go unanswered?

3.verse: Will your idle talk reduce others to silence?

4.verse: You say to God, ‘My beliefs are flawless

5.verse: Oh, how I wish that God would speak,

6.verse: and disclose to you the secrets of wisdom,

7.verse: “Can you fathom the mysteries of God?

8.verse: They are higher than the heavens above—what can you do?

9.verse: Their measure is longer than the earth

10.verse: “If he comes along and confines you in prison

11.verse: Surely he recognizes deceivers;

12.verse: But the witless can no more become wise

13.verse: “Yet if you devote your heart to him

14.verse: if you put away the sin that is in your hand

15.verse: then, free of fault, you will lift up your face;

16.verse: You will surely forget your trouble,

17.verse: Life will be brighter than noonday,

18.verse: You will be secure, because there is hope;

19.verse: You will lie down, with no one to make you afraid,

20.verse: But the eyes of the wicked will fail,

2.verse: “Doubtless you are the only people who matter,

3.verse: But I have a mind as well as you;

4.verse: “I have become a laughingstock to my friends,

5.verse: Those who are at ease have contempt for misfortune

6.verse: The tents of marauders are undisturbed,

7.verse: “But ask the animals, and they will teach you,

8.verse: or speak to the earth, and it will teach you,

9.verse: Which of all these does not know

10.verse: In his hand is the life of every creature

11.verse: Does not the ear test words

12.verse: Is not wisdom found among the aged?

13.verse: “To God belong wisdom and power;

14.verse: What he tears down cannot be rebuilt;

15.verse: If he holds back the waters, there is drought;

16.verse: To him belong strength and insight;

17.verse: He leads rulers away stripped

18.verse: He takes off the shackles put on by kings

19.verse: He leads priests away stripped

20.verse: He silences the lips of trusted advisers

21.verse: He pours contempt on nobles

22.verse: He reveals the deep things of darkness

23.verse: He makes nations great, and destroys them;

24.verse: He deprives the leaders of the earth of their reason;

25.verse: They grope in darkness with no light;

2.verse: What you know, I also know;

3.verse: But I desire to speak to the Almighty

4.verse: You, however, smear me with lies;

5.verse: If only you would be altogether silent!

6.verse: Hear now my argument;

7.verse: Will you speak wickedly on God’s behalf?

8.verse: Will you show him partiality?

9.verse: Would it turn out well if he examined you?

10.verse: He would surely call you to account

11.verse: Would not his splendor terrify you?

12.verse: Your maxims are proverbs of ashes;

13.verse: “Keep silent and let me speak;

14.verse: Why do I put myself in jeopardy

15.verse: Though he slay me, yet will I hope in him;

16.verse: Indeed, this will turn out for my deliverance,

17.verse: Listen carefully to what I say;

18.verse: Now that I have prepared my case,

19.verse: Can anyone bring charges against me?

20.verse: “Only grant me these two things, God,

21.verse: Withdraw your hand far from me,

22.verse: Then summon me and I will answer,

23.verse: How many wrongs and sins have I committed?

24.verse: Why do you hide your face

25.verse: Will you torment a windblown leaf?

26.verse: For you write down bitter things against me

27.verse: You fasten my feet in shackles;

28.verse: “So man wastes away like something rotten,

2.verse: They spring up like flowers and wither away;

3.verse: Do you fix your eye on them?

4.verse: Who can bring what is pure from the impure?

5.verse: A person’s days are determined;

6.verse: So look away from him and let him alone,

7.verse: “At least there is hope for a tree:

8.verse: Its roots may grow old in the ground

9.verse: yet at the scent of water it will bud

10.verse: But a man dies and is laid low;

11.verse: As the water of a lake dries up

12.verse: so he lies down and does not rise;

13.verse: “If only you would hide me in the grave

14.verse: If someone dies, will they live again?

15.verse: You will call and I will answer you;

16.verse: Surely then you will count my steps

17.verse: My offenses will be sealed up in a bag;

18.verse: “But as a mountain erodes and crumbles

19.verse: as water wears away stones

20.verse: You overpower them once for all, and they are gone;

21.verse: If their children are honored, they do not know it;

22.verse: They feel but the pain of their own bodies

2.verse: “Would a wise person answer with empty notions

3.verse: Would they argue with useless words,

4.verse: But you even undermine piety

5.verse: Your sin prompts your mouth;

6.verse: Your own mouth condemns you, not mine;

7.verse: “Are you the first man ever born?

8.verse: Do you listen in on God’s council?

9.verse: What do you know that we do not know?

10.verse: The gray-haired and the aged are on our side,

11.verse: Are God’s consolations not enough for you,

12.verse: Why has your heart carried you away,

13.verse: so that you vent your rage against God

14.verse: “What are mortals, that they could be pure,

15.verse: If God places no trust in his holy ones,

16.verse: how much less mortals, who are vile and corrupt,

17.verse: “Listen to me and I will explain to you;

18.verse: what the wise have declared,

19.verse: (to whom alone the land was given

20.verse: All his days the wicked man suffers torment,

21.verse: Terrifying sounds fill his ears;

22.verse: He despairs of escaping the realm of darkness;

23.verse: He wanders about for food like a vulture;

24.verse: Distress and anguish fill him with terror;

25.verse: because he shakes his fist at God

27.verse: “Though his face is covered with fat

29.verse: He will no longer be rich and his wealth will not endure,

30.verse: He will not escape the darkness;

31.verse: Let him not deceive himself by trusting what is worthless,

32.verse: Before his time he will wither,

33.verse: He will be like a vine stripped of its unripe grapes,

34.verse: For the company of the godless will be barren,

35.verse: They conceive trouble and give birth to evil;

2.verse: “I have heard many things like these;

3.verse: Will your long-winded speeches never end?

4.verse: I also could speak like you,

5.verse: But my mouth would encourage you;

6.verse: “Yet if I speak, my pain is not relieved;

7.verse: Surely, God, you have worn me out;

8.verse: You have shriveled me up—and it has become a witness;

9.verse: God assails me and tears me in his anger

10.verse: People open their mouths to jeer at me;

11.verse: God has turned me over to the ungodly

12.verse: All was well with me, but he shattered me;

13.verse: his archers surround me.

14.verse: Again and again he bursts upon me;

15.verse: “I have sewed sackcloth over my skin

16.verse: My face is red with weeping,

17.verse: yet my hands have been free of violence

18.verse: “Earth, do not cover my blood;

19.verse: Even now my witness is in heaven;

20.verse: My intercessor is my friend

21.verse: on behalf of a man he pleads with God

22.verse: “Only a few years will pass

2.verse: Surely mockers surround me;

3.verse: “Give me, O God, the pledge you demand.

4.verse: You have closed their minds to understanding;

5.verse: If anyone denounces their friends for reward,

6.verse: “God has made me a byword to everyone,

7.verse: My eyes have grown dim with grief;

8.verse: The upright are appalled at this;

9.verse: Nevertheless, the righteous will hold to their ways,

10.verse: “But come on, all of you, try again!

11.verse: My days have passed, my plans are shattered.

12.verse: turn night into day;

13.verse: If the only home I hope for is the grave,

14.verse: if I say to corruption, ‘You are my father,’

15.verse: where then is my hope—

16.verse: Will it go down to the gates of death?

2.verse: “When will you end these speeches?

3.verse: Why are we regarded as cattle

4.verse: You who tear yourself to pieces in your anger,

6.verse: The light in his tent becomes dark;

7.verse: The vigor of his step is weakened;

8.verse: His feet thrust him into a net;

9.verse: A trap seizes him by the heel;

10.verse: A noose is hidden for him on the ground;

11.verse: Terrors startle him on every side

12.verse: Calamity is hungry for him;

13.verse: It eats away parts of his skin;

14.verse: He is torn from the security of his tent

15.verse: Fire resides in his tent;

16.verse: His roots dry up below

17.verse: The memory of him perishes from the earth;

18.verse: He is driven from light into the realm of darkness

2.verse: “How long will you torment me

3.verse: Ten times now you have reproached me;

4.verse: If it is true that I have gone astray,

5.verse: If indeed you would exalt yourselves above me

6.verse: then know that God has wronged me

7.verse: “Though I cry, ‘Violence!’ I get no response;

8.verse: He has blocked my way so I cannot pass;

9.verse: He has stripped me of my honor

10.verse: He tears me down on every side till I am gone;

11.verse: His anger burns against me;

12.verse: His troops advance in force;

13.verse: “He has alienated my family from me;

14.verse: My relatives have gone away;

15.verse: My guests and my female servants count me a foreigner;

16.verse: I summon my servant, but he does not answer,

17.verse: My breath is offensive to my wife;

18.verse: Even the little boys scorn me;

19.verse: All my intimate friends detest me;

20.verse: I am nothing but skin and bones;

21.verse: “Have pity on me, my friends, have pity,

22.verse: Why do you pursue me as God does?

23.verse: “Oh, that my words were recorded,

24.verse: that they were inscribed with an iron tool on lead,

25.verse: I know that my redeemer lives,

26.verse: And after my skin has been destroyed,

28.verse: “If you say, ‘How we will hound him,

2.verse: “My troubled thoughts prompt me to answer

3.verse: I hear a rebuke that dishonors me,

4.verse: “Surely you know how it has been from of old,

5.verse: that the mirth of the wicked is brief,

6.verse: Though the pride of the godless person reaches to the heavens

7.verse: he will perish forever, like his own dung;

8.verse: Like a dream he flies away, no more to be found,

9.verse: The eye that saw him will not see him again;

10.verse: His children must make amends to the poor;

11.verse: The youthful vigor that fills his bones

12.verse: “Though evil is sweet in his mouth

13.verse: though he cannot bear to let it go

14.verse: yet his food will turn sour in his stomach;

15.verse: He will spit out the riches he swallowed;

16.verse: He will suck the poison of serpents;

17.verse: He will not enjoy the streams,

18.verse: What he toiled for he must give back uneaten;

19.verse: For he has oppressed the poor and left them destitute;

20.verse: “Surely he will have no respite from his craving;

21.verse: Nothing is left for him to devour;

22.verse: In the midst of his plenty, distress will overtake him;

23.verse: When he has filled his belly,

24.verse: Though he flees from an iron weapon,

25.verse: He pulls it out of his back,

26.verse: total darkness lies in wait for his treasures.

27.verse: The heavens will expose his guilt;

28.verse: A flood will carry off his house,

29.verse: Such is the fate God allots the wicked,

2.verse: “Listen carefully to my words;

3.verse: Bear with me while I speak,

4.verse: “Is my complaint directed to a human being?

5.verse: Look at me and be appalled;

6.verse: When I think about this, I am terrified;

7.verse: Why do the wicked live on,

8.verse: They see their children established around them,

9.verse: Their homes are safe and free from fear;

10.verse: Their bulls never fail to breed;

11.verse: They send forth their children as a flock;

12.verse: They sing to the music of timbrel and lyre;

14.verse: Yet they say to God, ‘Leave us alone!

15.verse: Who is the Almighty, that we should serve him?

16.verse: But their prosperity is not in their own hands,

17.verse: “Yet how often is the lamp of the wicked snuffed out?

18.verse: How often are they like straw before the wind,

19.verse: It is said, ‘God stores up the punishment of the wicked for their children.’

20.verse: Let their own eyes see their destruction;

21.verse: For what do they care about the families they leave behind

22.verse: “Can anyone teach knowledge to God,

24.verse: well nourished in body,

26.verse: Side by side they lie in the dust,

27.verse: “I know full well what you are thinking,

28.verse: You say, ‘Where now is the house of the great,

29.verse: Have you never questioned those who travel?

30.verse: that the wicked are spared from the day of calamity,

31.verse: Who denounces their conduct to their face?

34.verse: “So how can you console me with your nonsense?

2.verse: “Can a man be of benefit to God?

3.verse: What pleasure would it give the Almighty if you were righteous?

4.verse: “Is it for your piety that he rebukes you

5.verse: Is not your wickedness great?

6.verse: You demanded security from your relatives for no reason;

7.verse: You gave no water to the weary

8.verse: though you were a powerful man, owning land —

9.verse: And you sent widows away empty-handed

10.verse: That is why snares are all around you,

11.verse: why it is so dark you cannot see,

12.verse: “Is not God in the heights of heaven?

13.verse: Yet you say, ‘What does God know?

15.verse: Will you keep to the old path

16.verse: They were carried off before their time,

17.verse: They said to God, ‘Leave us alone!

18.verse: Yet it was he who filled their houses with good things,

19.verse: The righteous see their ruin and rejoice;

20.verse: ‘Surely our foes are destroyed,

21.verse: “Submit to God and be at peace with him;

22.verse: Accept instruction from his mouth

23.verse: If you return to the Almighty, you will be restored:

24.verse: and assign your nuggets to the dust,

25.verse: then the Almighty will be your gold,

26.verse: Surely then you will find delight in the Almighty

27.verse: You will pray to him, and he will hear you,

2.verse: “Even today my complaint is bitter;

3.verse: If only I knew where to find him;

4.verse: I would state my case before him

5.verse: I would find out what he would answer me,

6.verse: Would he vigorously oppose me?

7.verse: There the upright can establish their innocence before him,

8.verse: “But if I go to the east, he is not there;

9.verse: When he is at work in the north, I do not see him;

10.verse: But he knows the way that I take;

11.verse: My feet have closely followed his steps;

12.verse: I have not departed from the commands of his lips;

13.verse: “But he stands alone, and who can oppose him?

14.verse: He carries out his decree against me,

15.verse: That is why I am terrified before him;

16.verse: God has made my heart faint;

17.verse: Yet I am not silenced by the darkness,

1.verse: “Why does the Almighty not set times for judgment?

2.verse: There are those who move boundary stones;

3.verse: They drive away the orphan’s donkey

4.verse: They thrust the needy from the path

5.verse: Like wild donkeys in the desert,

6.verse: They gather fodder in the fields

7.verse: Lacking clothes, they spend the night naked;

8.verse: They are drenched by mountain rains

9.verse: The fatherless child is snatched from the breast;

10.verse: Lacking clothes, they go about naked;

11.verse: They crush olives among the terraces ;

12.verse: The groans of the dying rise from the city,

13.verse: “There are those who rebel against the light,

14.verse: When daylight is gone, the murderer rises up,

15.verse: The eye of the adulterer watches for dusk;

16.verse: In the dark, thieves break into houses,

17.verse: For all of them, midnight is their morning;

18.verse: “Yet they are foam on the surface of the water;

19.verse: As heat and drought snatch away the melted snow,

20.verse: The womb forgets them,

21.verse: They prey on the barren and childless woman,

22.verse: But God drags away the mighty by his power;

23.verse: He may let them rest in a feeling of security,

24.verse: For a little while they are exalted, and then they are gone;

25.verse: “If this is not so, who can prove me false

2.verse: “Dominion and awe belong to God;

3.verse: Can his forces be numbered?

4.verse: How then can a mortal be righteous before God?

5.verse: If even the moon is not bright

6.verse: how much less a mortal, who is but a maggot—

2.verse: “How you have helped the powerless!

3.verse: What advice you have offered to one without wisdom!

4.verse: Who has helped you utter these words?

5.verse: “The dead are in deep anguish,

6.verse: The realm of the dead is naked before God;

7.verse: He spreads out the northern skies over empty space;

8.verse: He wraps up the waters in his clouds,

9.verse: He covers the face of the full moon,

10.verse: He marks out the horizon on the face of the waters

11.verse: The pillars of the heavens quake,

12.verse: By his power he churned up the sea;

13.verse: By his breath the skies became fair;

14.verse: And these are but the outer fringe of his works;

2.verse: “As surely as God lives, who has denied me justice,

3.verse: as long as I have life within me,

4.verse: my lips will not say anything wicked,

5.verse: I will never admit you are in the right;

6.verse: I will maintain my innocence and never let go of it;

7.verse: “May my enemy be like the wicked,

8.verse: For what hope have the godless when they are cut off,

9.verse: Does God listen to their cry

10.verse: Will they find delight in the Almighty?

11.verse: “I will teach you about the power of God;

12.verse: You have all seen this yourselves.

13.verse: “Here is the fate God allots to the wicked,

14.verse: However many his children, their fate is the sword;

15.verse: The plague will bury those who survive him,

16.verse: Though he heaps up silver like dust

17.verse: what he lays up the righteous will wear,

18.verse: The house he builds is like a moth’s cocoon,

19.verse: He lies down wealthy, but will do so no more;

20.verse: Terrors overtake him like a flood;

21.verse: The east wind carries him off, and he is gone;

23.verse: It claps its hands in derision

1.verse: There is a mine for silver

2.verse: Iron is taken from the earth,

3.verse: Mortals put an end to the darkness;

4.verse: Far from human dwellings they cut a shaft,

5.verse: The earth, from which food comes,

6.verse: lapis lazuli comes from its rocks,

7.verse: No bird of prey knows that hidden path,

8.verse: Proud beasts do not set foot on it,

9.verse: People assault the flinty rock with their hands

10.verse: They tunnel through the rock;

11.verse: They search the sources of the rivers

12.verse: But where can wisdom be found?

13.verse: No mortal comprehends its worth;

14.verse: The deep says, “It is not in me”;

15.verse: It cannot be bought with the finest gold,

16.verse: It cannot be bought with the gold of Ophir,

17.verse: Neither gold nor crystal can compare with it,

18.verse: Coral and jasper are not worthy of mention;

19.verse: The topaz of Cush cannot compare with it;

22.verse: Destruction and Death say,

23.verse: God understands the way to it

24.verse: for he views the ends of the earth

25.verse: When he established the force of the wind

26.verse: when he made a decree for the rain

28.verse: And he said to the human race,

2.verse: “How I long for the months gone by,

3.verse: when his lamp shone on my head

4.verse: Oh, for the days when I was in my prime,

5.verse: when the Almighty was still with me

6.verse: when my path was drenched with cream

7.verse: “When I went to the gate of the city

8.verse: the young men saw me and stepped aside

9.verse: the chief men refrained from speaking

10.verse: the voices of the nobles were hushed,

11.verse: Whoever heard me spoke well of me,

12.verse: because I rescued the poor who cried for help,

13.verse: The one who was dying blessed me;

14.verse: I put on righteousness as my clothing;

15.verse: I was eyes to the blind

16.verse: I was a father to the needy;

17.verse: I broke the fangs of the wicked

18.verse: “I thought, ‘I will die in my own house,

19.verse: My roots will reach to the water,

20.verse: My glory will not fade;

21.verse: “People listened to me expectantly,

22.verse: After I had spoken, they spoke no more;

23.verse: They waited for me as for showers

24.verse: When I smiled at them, they scarcely believed it;

25.verse: I chose the way for them and sat as their chief;

2.verse: Of what use was the strength of their hands to me,

3.verse: Haggard from want and hunger,

4.verse: In the brush they gathered salt herbs,

5.verse: They were banished from human society,

6.verse: They were forced to live in the dry stream beds,

7.verse: They brayed among the bushes

8.verse: A base and nameless brood,

9.verse: “And now those young men mock me in song;

10.verse: They detest me and keep their distance;

11.verse: Now that God has unstrung my bow and afflicted me,

12.verse: On my right the tribe attacks;

13.verse: They break up my road;

14.verse: They advance as through a gaping breach;

15.verse: Terrors overwhelm me;

16.verse: “And now my life ebbs away;

17.verse: Night pierces my bones;

18.verse: In his great power God becomes like clothing to me ;

19.verse: He throws me into the mud,

20.verse: “I cry out to you, God, but you do not answer;

21.verse: You turn on me ruthlessly;

22.verse: You snatch me up and drive me before the wind;

23.verse: I know you will bring me down to death,

24.verse: “Surely no one lays a hand on a broken man

25.verse: Have I not wept for those in trouble?

26.verse: Yet when I hoped for good, evil came;

27.verse: The churning inside me never stops;

28.verse: I go about blackened, but not by the sun;

29.verse: I have become a brother of jackals,

30.verse: My skin grows black and peels;

31.verse: My lyre is tuned to mourning,

1.verse: “I made a covenant with my eyes

2.verse: For what is our lot from God above,

3.verse: Is it not ruin for the wicked,

4.verse: Does he not see my ways

5.verse: “If I have walked with falsehood

6.verse: let God weigh me in honest scales

7.verse: if my steps have turned from the path,

8.verse: then may others eat what I have sown,

9.verse: “If my heart has been enticed by a woman,

10.verse: then may my wife grind another man’s grain,

11.verse: For that would have been wicked,

12.verse: It is a fire that burns to Destruction ;

13.verse: “If I have denied justice to any of my servants,

14.verse: what will I do when God confronts me?

15.verse: Did not he who made me in the womb make them?

16.verse: “If I have denied the desires of the poor

17.verse: if I have kept my bread to myself,

18.verse: but from my youth I reared them as a father would,

19.verse: if I have seen anyone perishing for lack of clothing,

20.verse: and their hearts did not bless me

21.verse: if I have raised my hand against the fatherless,

22.verse: then let my arm fall from the shoulder,

23.verse: For I dreaded destruction from God,

24.verse: “If I have put my trust in gold

25.verse: if I have rejoiced over my great wealth,

26.verse: if I have regarded the sun in its radiance

27.verse: so that my heart was secretly enticed

28.verse: then these also would be sins to be judged,

29.verse: “If I have rejoiced at my enemy’s misfortune

30.verse: I have not allowed my mouth to sin

31.verse: if those of my household have never said,

32.verse: but no stranger had to spend the night in the street,

33.verse: if I have concealed my sin as people do,

34.verse: because I so feared the crowd

35.verse: (“Oh, that I had someone to hear me!

36.verse: Surely I would wear it on my shoulder,

37.verse: I would give him an account of my every step;

38.verse: “if my land cries out against me

39.verse: if I have devoured its yield without payment

40.verse: then let briers come up instead of wheat

1.verse: So these three men stopped answering Job, because he was righteous in his own eyes.

2.verse: But Elihu son of Barakel the Buzite, of the family of Ram, became very angry with Job for justifying himself rather than God.

3.verse: He was also angry with the three friends, because they had found no way to refute Job, and yet had condemned him.

4.verse: Now Elihu had waited before speaking to Job because they were older than he.

5.verse: But when he saw that the three men had nothing more to say, his anger was aroused.

6.verse: So Elihu son of Barakel the Buzite said:

7.verse: I thought, ‘Age should speak;

8.verse: But it is the spirit in a person,

9.verse: It is not only the old who are wise,

10.verse: “Therefore I say: Listen to me;

11.verse: I waited while you spoke,

12.verse: I gave you my full attention.

13.verse: Do not say, ‘We have found wisdom;

14.verse: But Job has not marshaled his words against me,

15.verse: “They are dismayed and have no more to say;

16.verse: Must I wait, now that they are silent,

17.verse: I too will have my say;

18.verse: For I am full of words,

19.verse: inside I am like bottled-up wine,

20.verse: I must speak and find relief;

21.verse: I will show no partiality,

22.verse: for if I were skilled in flattery,

1.verse: “But now, Job, listen to my words;

2.verse: I am about to open my mouth;

3.verse: My words come from an upright heart;

4.verse: The Spirit of God has made me;

5.verse: Answer me then, if you can;

6.verse: I am the same as you in God’s sight;

7.verse: No fear of me should alarm you,

8.verse: “But you have said in my hearing—

9.verse: ‘I am pure, I have done no wrong;

10.verse: Yet God has found fault with me;

11.verse: He fastens my feet in shackles;

12.verse: “But I tell you, in this you are not right,

13.verse: Why do you complain to him

14.verse: For God does speak —now one way, now another —

15.verse: In a dream, in a vision of the night,

16.verse: he may speak in their ears

17.verse: to turn them from wrongdoing

18.verse: to preserve them from the pit,

19.verse: “Or someone may be chastened on a bed of pain

20.verse: so that their body finds food repulsive

21.verse: Their flesh wastes away to nothing,

22.verse: They draw near to the pit,

23.verse: Yet if there is an angel at their side,

24.verse: and he is gracious to that person and says to God,

25.verse: let their flesh be renewed like a child’s;

26.verse: then that person can pray to God and find favor with him,

27.verse: And they will go to others and say,

28.verse: God has delivered me from going down to the pit,

29.verse: “God does all these things to a person —

30.verse: to turn them back from the pit,

31.verse: “Pay attention, Job, and listen to me;

32.verse: If you have anything to say, answer me;

33.verse: But if not, then listen to me;

2.verse: “Hear my words, you wise men;

3.verse: For the ear tests words

4.verse: Let us discern for ourselves what is right;

5.verse: “Job says, ‘I am innocent,

6.verse: Although I am right,

7.verse: Is there anyone like Job,

8.verse: He keeps company with evildoers;

9.verse: For he says, ‘There is no profit

10.verse: “So listen to me, you men of understanding.

11.verse: He repays everyone for what they have done;

12.verse: It is unthinkable that God would do wrong,

13.verse: Who appointed him over the earth?

14.verse: If it were his intention

15.verse: all humanity would perish together

16.verse: “If you have understanding, hear this;

17.verse: Can someone who hates justice govern?

18.verse: Is he not the One who says to kings, ‘You are worthless,’

19.verse: who shows no partiality to princes

20.verse: They die in an instant, in the middle of the night;

21.verse: “His eyes are on the ways of mortals;

22.verse: There is no deep shadow, no utter darkness,

23.verse: God has no need to examine people further,

24.verse: Without inquiry he shatters the mighty

25.verse: Because he takes note of their deeds,

26.verse: He punishes them for their wickedness

27.verse: because they turned from following him

28.verse: They caused the cry of the poor to come before him,

29.verse: But if he remains silent, who can condemn him?

30.verse: to keep the godless from ruling,

32.verse: Teach me what I cannot see;

33.verse: Should God then reward you on your terms,

36.verse: Oh, that Job might be tested to the utmost

37.verse: To his sin he adds rebellion;

2.verse: “Do you think this is just?

3.verse: Yet you ask him, ‘What profit is it to me,

4.verse: “I would like to reply to you

5.verse: Look up at the heavens and see;

6.verse: If you sin, how does that affect him?

7.verse: If you are righteous, what do you give to him,

8.verse: Your wickedness only affects humans like yourself,

9.verse: “People cry out under a load of oppression;

10.verse: But no one says, ‘Where is God my Maker,

11.verse: who teaches us more than he teaches the beasts of the earth

12.verse: He does not answer when people cry out

13.verse: Indeed, God does not listen to their empty plea;

14.verse: How much less, then, will he listen

15.verse: and further, that his anger never punishes

2.verse: “Bear with me a little longer and I will show you

3.verse: I get my knowledge from afar;

4.verse: Be assured that my words are not false;

5.verse: “God is mighty, but despises no one;

6.verse: He does not keep the wicked alive

7.verse: He does not take his eyes off the righteous;

8.verse: But if people are bound in chains,

9.verse: he tells them what they have done—

10.verse: He makes them listen to correction

11.verse: If they obey and serve him,

12.verse: But if they do not listen,

13.verse: “The godless in heart harbor resentment;

14.verse: They die in their youth,

15.verse: But those who suffer he delivers in their suffering;

16.verse: “He is wooing you from the jaws of distress

17.verse: But now you are laden with the judgment due the wicked;

18.verse: Be careful that no one entices you by riches;

19.verse: Would your wealth or even all your mighty efforts

20.verse: Do not long for the night,

21.verse: Beware of turning to evil,

22.verse: “God is exalted in his power.

23.verse: Who has prescribed his ways for him,

24.verse: Remember to extol his work,

25.verse: All humanity has seen it;

26.verse: How great is God—beyond our understanding!

27.verse: “He draws up the drops of water,

28.verse: the clouds pour down their moisture

29.verse: Who can understand how he spreads out the clouds,

30.verse: See how he scatters his lightning about him,

31.verse: This is the way he governs the nations

32.verse: He fills his hands with lightning

33.verse: His thunder announces the coming storm;

2.verse: Listen! Listen to the roar of his voice,

3.verse: He unleashes his lightning beneath the whole heaven

4.verse: After that comes the sound of his roar;

5.verse: God’s voice thunders in marvelous ways;

6.verse: He says to the snow, ‘Fall on the earth,’

7.verse: So that everyone he has made may know his work,

8.verse: The animals take cover;

9.verse: The tempest comes out from its chamber,

10.verse: The breath of God produces ice,

11.verse: He loads the clouds with moisture;

12.verse: At his direction they swirl around

13.verse: He brings the clouds to punish people,

14.verse: “Listen to this, Job;

15.verse: Do you know how God controls the clouds

16.verse: Do you know how the clouds hang poised,

17.verse: You who swelter in your clothes

18.verse: can you join him in spreading out the skies,

19.verse: “Tell us what we should say to him;

20.verse: Should he be told that I want to speak?

21.verse: Now no one can look at the sun,

22.verse: Out of the north he comes in golden splendor;

23.verse: The Almighty is beyond our reach and exalted in power;

24.verse: Therefore, people revere him,

1.verse: Then the Lord spoke to Job out of the storm. He said:

2.verse: “Who is this that obscures my plans

3.verse: Brace yourself like a man;

4.verse: “Where were you when I laid the earth’s foundation?

5.verse: Who marked off its dimensions? Surely you know!

6.verse: On what were its footings set,

7.verse: while the morning stars sang together

8.verse: “Who shut up the sea behind doors

9.verse: when I made the clouds its garment

10.verse: when I fixed limits for it

11.verse: when I said, ‘This far you may come and no farther;

12.verse: “Have you ever given orders to the morning,

13.verse: that it might take the earth by the edges

15.verse: The wicked are denied their light,

16.verse: “Have you journeyed to the springs of the sea

17.verse: Have the gates of death been shown to you?

18.verse: Have you comprehended the vast expanses of the earth?

19.verse: “What is the way to the abode of light?

20.verse: Can you take them to their places?

21.verse: Surely you know, for you were already born!

22.verse: “Have you entered the storehouses of the snow

23.verse: which I reserve for times of trouble,

24.verse: What is the way to the place where the lightning is dispersed,

25.verse: Who cuts a channel for the torrents of rain,

26.verse: to water a land where no one lives,

28.verse: Does the rain have a father?

29.verse: From whose womb comes the ice?

30.verse: when the waters become hard as stone,

31.verse: “Can you bind the chains of the Pleiades?

32.verse: Can you bring forth the constellations in their seasons

33.verse: Do you know the laws of the heavens?

34.verse: “Can you raise your voice to the clouds

35.verse: Do you send the lightning bolts on their way?

37.verse: Who has the wisdom to count the clouds?

39.verse: “Do you hunt the prey for the lioness

40.verse: when they crouch in their dens

41.verse: Who provides food for the raven

1.verse: “Do you know when the mountain goats give birth?

2.verse: Do you count the months till they bear?

3.verse: They crouch down and bring forth their young;

4.verse: Their young thrive and grow strong in the wilds;

5.verse: “Who let the wild donkey go free?

6.verse: I gave it the wasteland as its home,

7.verse: It laughs at the commotion in the town;

8.verse: It ranges the hills for its pasture

9.verse: “Will the wild ox consent to serve you?

11.verse: Will you rely on it for its great strength?

12.verse: Can you trust it to haul in your grain

14.verse: She lays her eggs on the ground

15.verse: unmindful that a foot may crush them,

16.verse: She treats her young harshly, as if they were not hers;

17.verse: for God did not endow her with wisdom

18.verse: Yet when she spreads her feathers to run,

19.verse: “Do you give the horse its strength

20.verse: Do you make it leap like a locust,

21.verse: It paws fiercely, rejoicing in its strength,

22.verse: It laughs at fear, afraid of nothing;

23.verse: The quiver rattles against its side,

24.verse: In frenzied excitement it eats up the ground;

25.verse: At the blast of the trumpet it snorts, ‘Aha!’

26.verse: “Does the hawk take flight by your wisdom

27.verse: Does the eagle soar at your command

29.verse: From there it looks for food;

30.verse: Its young ones feast on blood,

2.verse: “Will the one who contends with the Almighty correct him?

3.verse: Then Job answered the Lord :

4.verse: “I am unworthy —how can I reply to you?

5.verse: I spoke once, but I have no answer —

6.verse: Then the Lord spoke to Job out of the storm:

7.verse: “Brace yourself like a man;

8.verse: “Would you discredit my justice?

9.verse: Do you have an arm like God’s,

10.verse: Then adorn yourself with glory and splendor,

11.verse: Unleash the fury of your wrath,

12.verse: look at all who are proud and humble them,

13.verse: Bury them all in the dust together;

14.verse: Then I myself will admit to you

15.verse: “Look at Behemoth,

16.verse: What strength it has in its loins,

17.verse: Its tail sways like a cedar;

18.verse: Its bones are tubes of bronze,

19.verse: It ranks first among the works of God,

20.verse: The hills bring it their produce,

21.verse: Under the lotus plants it lies,

22.verse: The lotuses conceal it in their shadow;

23.verse: A raging river does not alarm it;

24.verse: Can anyone capture it by the eyes,

1.verse: “Can you pull in Leviathan with a fishhook

2.verse: Can you put a cord through its nose

3.verse: Will it keep begging you for mercy?

4.verse: Will it make an agreement with you

5.verse: Can you make a pet of it like a bird

6.verse: Will traders barter for it?

7.verse: Can you fill its hide with harpoons

8.verse: If you lay a hand on it,

9.verse: Any hope of subduing it is false;

10.verse: No one is fierce enough to rouse it.

11.verse: Who has a claim against me that I must pay?

12.verse: “I will not fail to speak of Leviathan’s limbs,

13.verse: Who can strip off its outer coat?

14.verse: Who dares open the doors of its mouth,

15.verse: Its back has rows of shields

16.verse: each is so close to the next

17.verse: They are joined fast to one another;

18.verse: Its snorting throws out flashes of light;

19.verse: Flames stream from its mouth;

20.verse: Smoke pours from its nostrils

21.verse: Its breath sets coals ablaze,

22.verse: Strength resides in its neck;

23.verse: The folds of its flesh are tightly joined;

24.verse: Its chest is hard as rock,

25.verse: When it rises up, the mighty are terrified;

26.verse: The sword that reaches it has no effect,

28.verse: Arrows do not make it flee;

29.verse: A club seems to it but a piece of straw;

31.verse: It makes the depths churn like a boiling caldron

32.verse: It leaves a glistening wake behind it;

33.verse: Nothing on earth is its equal —

34.verse: It looks down on all that are haughty;

1.verse: Then Job replied to the Lord :

2.verse: “I know that you can do all things;

5.verse: My ears had heard of you

6.verse: Therefore I despise myself

7.verse: After the Lord had said these things to Job , he said to Eliphaz the Temanite, “I am angry with you and your two friends, because you have not spoken the truth about me, as my servant Job has.

8.verse: So now take seven bulls and seven rams and go to my servant Job and sacrifice a burnt offering for yourselves. My servant Job will pray for you, and I will accept his prayer and not deal with you according to your folly. You have not spoken the truth about me, as my servant Job has.”

9.verse: So Eliphaz the Temanite, Bildad the Shuhite and Zophar the Naamathite did what the Lord told them; and the Lord accepted Job’s prayer.

10.verse: After Job had prayed for his friends, the Lord restored his fortunes and gave him twice as much as he had before.

11.verse: All his brothers and sisters and everyone who had known him before came and ate with him in his house. They comforted and consoled him over all the trouble the Lord had brought on him, and each one gave him a piece of silver and a gold ring.

12.verse: The Lord blessed the latter part of Job’s life more than the former part. He had fourteen thousand sheep, six thousand camels, a thousand yoke of oxen and a thousand donkeys.

13.verse: And he also had seven sons and three daughters.

14.verse: The first daughter he named Jemimah, the second Keziah and the third Keren-Happuch.

15.verse: Nowhere in all the land were there found women as beautiful as Job’s daughters, and their father granted them an inheritance along with their brothers.

16.verse: After this, Job lived a hundred and forty years; he saw his children and their children to the fourth generation.

17.verse: And so Job died, an old man and full of years.
